awd_titl_txt: Active Asteroids: Investigating Surface Structural Failure As a Source of Mass Loss
awd_abstract_narration:
Comets and asteroids are leftovers of the early stages of the creation of the Solar System when planets began to form.  Astronomers are interested in them as they are objects representative of the primitive Solar System material that made the planets.  Some asteroids have been observed with telescopes to show dust-loss activity normally seen only with comets.  These are called "active asteroids", as they have orbits and surface characteristics of asteroids. This grant will study whether an asteroid spinning around its axis disrupts dust or particles on its surface, which are then shed off the surface of the asteroid in a landslide, creating the comet-like activity that is observed. If this process is happening, it is linked to the types of materials in the dust layer on the surface of the asteroid. The investigators will study how and why this is happening, using experiments and comparing the results with telescopic observations.  This project supports the mission of the NSF by promoting our understanding of the composition and structure of primitive materials used to create the early planets in our Solar System.  The lead investigator will recruit and guide undergraduate students for experiment design, manufacturing, operation, and data analysis in the Center for Microgravity Research laboratory, exposing them to hands-on space-related activities.

The active asteroids are classified as asteroids because their dynamical and spectral characteristics clearly tie them to asteroid taxonomy classes, yet they display activity in the form of particle loss at rates ranging from 10^-2 to 10^-4 kg/s. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that mass shedding on small asteroids can occur due to landslides, a process intimately linked to the material and mechanical properties of regolith (the asteroid's surface dust layer). The proposed work will investigate regolith structural failure from rotational disruption as a possible origin for the dust ejection activity observed on a number of these asteroids, for which other dust production mechanisms were ruled out.  The investigators combine laboratory experiments with regolith simulants, numerical simulations, and corroboration with ground-based telescopic observations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

Active asteroids are asteroids that show comet-like activity. Our project investigated rotational disruption as a possible origin for the dust ejection activity observed on a number of these asteroids, for which other dust production mechanisms were ruled out. The central hypothesis of this work was that mass shedding on small asteroids can occur due to landslides, a process intimately linked to the material and mechanical properties of regolith. Therefore, the goal of the project was to determine the role of material strength on the mechanisms of mass shedding on small asteroids.



Intellectual Merit

Our approach focused around collecting laboratory data on material strength for simulated asteroid materials in relevant environmental conditions. In particular, we investigated:

- the role of grain size on asteroid material strength, as well as size mixtures;

- the role of a microgravity environment;

- the role of a water ice fraction.

Our work contributed to a better understanding of how granular materials behave on small bodies. Beyond providing a potential mechanism for regular dust ejection events on active asteroids that does not require the presence of large quantities of volatiles, it also offered insights into a potential mechanism for distant activity observed on small icy bodies in the outskirts of our solar system, such as Centaurs and Trans-Neptunian Objects (TNOs). Such a mechanism would also allow for regular replenishing of ring systems around these same small icy bodies.



Broader Impacts

Over the course of the project, we have trained the following people:

- one postdoctoral researcher: 2020-2022

- 18 undergraduate students: 2018-2024

- one high-school student: 2018-2019

Training was provided on two different types of skills: (1) technical and scientific skills; and (2) mentoring and management skills. Technical and scientific skills were provided to new undergraduate students and a high-school trainee by other undergraduates, more senior in the FSI lab (some students stayed on the project several years). This training came in the form of one-on-one, hands-on sessions with the student mentor in the lab. Mentoring and management skills were also trained in the more senior students, by assigning them mentees and giving them responsibilities in the organization of experiment plans and their execution. Such skills were mentored by PI Brisset and provided the students with valuable experience for their future careers in technical or academic jobs.



Products and Publications

The project produced 5 publications, 1 book chapter, 4 published conference abstracts, and 7 conference presentations.

Publications:

  • Brisset, J., Sánchez, P., Cox, C., Corraliza, D., Hatchitt, J., Madison, A. and Miletich, T., 2022. Asteroid regolith strength: Role of grain size and surface properties. Planetary and Space Science, 220, p.105533.

  • Cox, C., Brisset, J., Partida, A., Madison, A. and Bitcon, O., 2024. Asteroid regolith strength: Role of fine-fractions. Planetary and Space Science, 240, p.105829.

  • Duffey, C., Lea, M. and Brisset, J., 2024. Measuring Regolith Strength in Reduced Gravity Environments in the Laboratory. arXiv preprint arXiv:2411.11571, accepted at Review of Scientific Instruments, 2025

  • Brisset, J., Léa, M., McNair, D., Duffey, C., Cox, C., Durham, A., Asteroid Material Strength: Role of Vacuum and Gravity, submitted to Planetary and Space Sciences

  • Brisset, J., Léa, M., McNair, D., Barrier, D., Johnson, I., Cox, C., Durham, A., Asteroid Material Strength: Role of Water Ice Content, in preparation

     

Book Chapter:

  • Brisset, J., Blum, J., Brunetto, R., Burchell, M., Grundy, W., Gudipati, M., Gundlach, B., Hénault, E., Laboratory Studies applicable to Centaurs, Centaur Review book chapter, IOP, 2025

 

Conference Presentations:

  • 2019: Oral presentation at the "Centaur Exploration Workshop" showing how laboratory measurements on icy regoliths can contribute to understanding small body activity. PI Brisset

  • 2019: Oral presentation at the workshop "The Main Belt: A Gateway to the Formation and Early Evolution of the Solar System" showing preliminary measurement results. PI Brisset

  • 2020: Oral presentation – contributed – at the American Astrophysical Society (AAS) Division of Planetary Sciences (DPS) annual meeting, showing first year project results. PI Brisset

  • 2020: Oral presentation – invited – at the AAS DPS annual meeting, showing how laboratory measurements on regolith can shed light on small body surface activity. PI Brisset

  • 2021: Oral presentation at the European Planetary Science Conference (EPSC) on the strength of fine-coarse grain mixtures in asteroids. This presentation was prepared and performed by an undergraduate student on the project. Student Cox

  • 2022: Oral presentation at the AAS DPS annual meeting in London, Canada, on the strength of fine-coarse grain mixtures in asteroids. This presentation was prepared and performed by an undergraduate student of the project. Student Cox

  • 2023: Plenary presentation at the Asteroid, Comets, Meteorites (ACM) Meeting in Flagstaff, AZ. PI Brisset.

 


Last Modified: 03/28/2025
Modified by: Julie Brisset

Image
  • Diagram illustrating how changes in surface material strength can lead to recurring activity on asteroids. Surface material gets weathered and modified by long-term exposure to the space environment. This leads to a change in material strength and shedding, and exposure to new surface material.
    Brisset, et al., 2025 (book chapter_
    Copyrighted
    Julie Brisset
    Surface Activity Driven by Regolith Strength

Project Overview


Active asteroids are asteroids that show comet-like activity. Our project investigated rotational disruption as a possible origin for the dust ejection activity observed on a number of these asteroids, for which other dust production mechanisms were ruled out. The central hypothesis of this work was that mass shedding on small asteroids can occur due to landslides, a process intimately linked to the material and mechanical properties of regolith. Therefore, the goal of the project was to determine the role of material strength on the mechanisms of mass shedding on small asteroids.

Our approach focused around collecting laboratory data on material strength for simulated asteroid materials in relevant environmental conditions. In particular, we investigated:

- the role of a microgravity environment;

Our work contributed to a better understanding of how granular materials behave on small bodies. Beyond providing a potential mechanism for regular dust ejection events on active asteroids that does not require the presence of large quantities of volatiles, it also offered insights into a potential mechanism for distant activity observed on small icy bodies in the outskirts of our solar system, such as Centaurs and Trans-Neptunian Objects (TNOs). Such a mechanism would also allow for regular replenishing of ring systems around these same small icy bodies.

Training was provided on two different types of skills: (1) technical and scientific skills; and (2) mentoring and management skills. Such skills were mentored by PI Brisset and provided the students with valuable experience for their future careers in technical or academic jobs.
